Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Combinatorial Algorithms for High-Throughput Collection and Analysis of Genomic Diversity Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Genomic diversity analyses of large-scale case/control and population studies promise to provide answers to fundamental problems ranging from determining the genetic basis of disease susceptibility to uncovering the pattern of historical population migrations. However, the feasibility of such studies critically depends on addressing a number of technological and computational challenges. On the technological front, despite the huge advances made in recent years, there is still a need for a flexible high-throughput platform capable of typing hundreds of thousands of SNPs at a very low-cost per experiment.Computationally, there is a need for integrating recently developed statistical models of the structure of genomic variability in human populations with efficient combinatorial methods delivering predictable solution quality.

The proposed research and education activities will address the above challenges at several levels, including modeling and formalizing the underlying biological and technological problems, finding efficient algorithms for the identified problems, engineering these algorithms into high-quality open-source bioinformatics tools, and collaborating closely with industry researchers and molecular geneticists in validating the proposed methods and applying them to population-scale genomic data. Major project outcomes will include (1) development of an innovative high-throughput SNP genotyping assay realizing a yet unrealized potential of k-mer arrays by combination with solution-phase single-base extension, (2) optimization of two proven technologies that are in common use in SNP genotyping - DNA tag arrays and multiplex-PCR, (3) novel likelihood maximization algorithms with predictable solution quality for challenging computational problems arising in two-stage sampling design association studies, including haplotype tagging SNP selection and haplotype reconstruction from genotype data, (4) robust open-source software implementations and principled methodologies for the empirical evaluation of proposed algorithms, and (5) innovative curriculum and educational materials, including the creation of a new textbook on computational genomics. The successful completion of the project will lead to decreased data collection costs in large-scale association studies, thus enabling more studies to be completed within the same budget. The proposed assay architecture based on k-mer arrays is expected to enable additional applications of genomic technologies, such as genomics-based point-of-care medical diagnosis and large-scale species identification. Broader impacts of proposed educational and outreach activities include increasing participation of under-represented groups in research and training of future researchers with unique interdisciplinary skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent technology advances have made it feasible to sequence the genome of any individual. However, the high error rate, fragmentary nature, and high cost of the sequencing data produced by current high-throughput technologies severely limit their wider adoption for biomedical research and clinical use. The main goal of this project has been to develop computational methods and software tools that increase the usefulness of sequencing data by correcting errors, accurately inferring missing information, and reducing sequencing depth requirements (and hence costs). 

Project outcomes include scalable bioinformatics tools for high-accuracy genotype calling, haplotype reconstruction, and local ancestry inference by integrated analysis of low-coverage individual sequencing data and reference population haplotype panels. We have also developed best-in-class methods for reconstruction of viral quasispecies sequences from shotgun or amplicon sequencing data and expectation-maximization algorithms for estimation of isoform and gene expression levels from RNA sequencing data. The source code of all developed tools is freely available at http://dna.engr.uconn.edu/software/. Many of the tools are also available under the Galaxy server maintained by our lab at http://rna1.engr.uconn.edu:7474/. To further increase adoption, several tools have been deployed as plugins for the ION Torrent Server, and are freely available in the Torrent Browser Plugin Store at http://ioncommunity.iontorrent.com.

The developed bioinformatics tools have been incorporated into complex analysis flows geared towards specific biomedical applications in collaboration with molecular biologists and medical researchers. For example, we have integrated our algorithms for variant calling from RNA sequencing data, individual haplotyping, and isoform expression estimation into a pipeline for estimation of allele-specific isoform expression levels which is currently being used in collaboration with Profs. Michael and Rachel O’Neill from the Molecular and Cell Biology at UConn to study the role of parental imprinting of gene expression in a mouse model of autism. Similarly, in collaboration with Prof. Pramod K. Srivastava from the Center for Immunotherapy of Cancer and Infectious Diseases at the UConn Health Center we have developed a bioinformatics pipeline to quickly and cost-effectively identify from RNA sequencing data tumor-specific epitopes that can be used in personalized cancer immunotherapy.

One post-doctoral scholar, eight Ph.D. students (four graduated), three M.S. students (all graduated), and seven undergraduate students (four graduated) have participated in research activities related to this project. Their participation has given them the chance to develop a deep understanding of the biological processes underlying genetic variation, to acquire research skills in mathematical modeling, statistical analysis, as well as algorithm design, analysis and implementation, and, last but not least, to enhance their capability of working effectively across disciplinary lines. Research involvement as undergraduates has been instrumental in the decision of three of the undergraduate students to continue pursuing Ph.D. studies in bioinformatics.
